ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The instructor was generally very responsive to questions, but there was very little, and often no time for them.

While the professor was clearly very knowledgable on the topics, I felt like he didn't impart his expertise very efficiently. We were given a lot of reading but we didn't spend much time going over the reading in class so it was unclear what the benefit of the reading was.
course mainly focused on the American Laws hence the other international students may not get exposed to the law of their land
Thorough review, intense expertise of the professor. I couldn't imagine anyone more qualified to teach this material.

I enjoyed watching the panel discussing TSCA reform. It was neat to read about TSCA and REACH and then see how the conversation is going in DC. I also really enjoyed the presentations by Dean Kyser and Bill Dornbos.
The Revesz textbook was a great resource.
The subject matter is critical to any environmental manager.
class discussions and anecdotes from the professor.
This course gives a nice overview of all of the major environmental statutes. The case readings are interesting.
The instructor made it very interactive

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Readings were a little confusing without going to a non-class source to read about the actual case.
The reading material is very dense and difficult to get through for those not already familiar with typical law school readings and language. Most students did not complete the readings.

The class lectures tented to digress and focus too closely on the Professor's own pontification about the topics. This kind of discussion would be appropriate only after actually presenting the nuts and bolts of the statutes the class was slated to go over during the class.

The course focused on statutes rather than how the law can be used to solve environmental problems. This was disappointing. As a non-YLS student, the course content was not as relevant as it could have been. On the other hand, it's quite possible that the nature of the material reflects the legal system as it exists.
getting into the case history in more depth by making class time more interesting, perhaps by asking a different student to present a specific case each class.

Additional assignments would be helpful in this class to make students apply what they're learning. The course should also have more structured lectures with the use of power point or some sort of format to follow.
It should have some exposure to the laws of the country to which a student belong.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: No TA. Professor was available if requested.

Professor Elliott did tailor the course to suit the interests of the students in the course. Inquiries communicated via email, however, were often met by curt, sometimes dismissive responses.He also did seem to make an effort to engage with some students over others.
The professor was available for help when needed.
Excellent and most dedicated instructor

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Great introduction to environmental law in the USA.
I think it's important for any environmental professional to understand the major environmental policies.

This class helped give me an overview of environmental policy and law, but we didn't go that into depth on any of the statutes since many of them are covered in the course. I'm interested in corporate sustainability so I wanted to learn about how laws affect companies and businesses.
It is talk of the time these days

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To have a familiarity with the major environmental policies.
I felt that understanding the legal and policy framework behind environmental problem solving was important to any well-rounded person working in the field of the environment.
To help my department in handling the environmental issues properly

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes.

I expected the course to be more of a broad overview on the major regulations and I didn't expect as much analysis of the fine details of case law. In that regard, it did not live up to my expectations.
No. This course was something of a disappointment, as I had heard good things about it from many of my classmates.
Not really. This course could have been much better if the lectures were more formatted and if we had to apply the readings to papers or other assignments throughout the semester.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
Not really. I was expecting a broader overview of environmental law. It was hard for me to keep up at times because of the lengthy and dense readings.
No. I did not learn as much as I could have. (I take the majority of the responsibility for this.)

Somewhat. I learned the majority of the material in the last week of the semester when I did many of the readings in preparation for the final exam. Don't do this! Try to read throughout the semester to absorb the material better.
More then that

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: no group work

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the reading, and read the case material outside of the casebook reader.
Form a reading group where students share the load of summarizing the readings. Rather than follow the readings word for word, consult online sources that help explain the significance of the cases.
Definitely take the time to read the textbook. It is helpful for understanding the statutes and will fill in the gaps in the Professor's lectures.
Do the reading!!!
Only take this if you are very disciplined to do the readings and follow the lectures closely. Otherwise you won't learn a whole lot.
They should be regular in classreadings
